introText: You can use this test to assess your company's compliance with the obligations of a controller. After submitting your answers, you will receive a report with compiled feedback on your answers and recommended measures based on them.

questions.question: How has your company identified the purposes of processing personal data?

choices.option: We have listed the purposes of processing in an internal document or table
choices.selectedText: The documentation of the purposes of processing helps you understand which data is necessary for those purposes and which basis provided in the GDPR you can use for processing personal data. There is no single correct way of drawing up the documentation. However, you are required to inform the data subjects of the purposes of processing, e.g. in your privacy statement. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/purpose-limitation

questions.guideText: The processing of personal data may be subject to special legislation in addition to the General Data Protection Regulation. Special legislation consists of enactments regulating personal data files that are significant for the functioning of society (for example the Population Information Register and registers related to study rights and study credits) and enactments providing for the processing of personal data related to specific sectors (Act on the Protection of Privacy in Working Life (https://tietosuoja.fi/tyoelaman-tietosuojalaki), Credit Rating Act (Luottotietolaki) and Act on the Status and Rights of Patients). There are also individual data protection provisions in other legislation.

questions.question: Are some of your company's personal data processing activities based on the legitimate interest of your company or another party?

choices.selectedText: The processing of personal data can sometimes be justified by the legitimate interest of the controller or a third party. For example, the processing of personal data can be in the legitimate interest of the controller when there is a significant relationship between the controller and data subject (for example, the data subject is the controller's customer or employee). Legitimate interest may apply to sending direct marketing to customers without the individual's specific consent, for example. Using legitimate interest as a basis for processing requires particularly careful consideration of the data subject's rights and interests. More information on legitimate interest: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/controller-s-legitimate-interests
choices.selectedActions: Double-check that legitimate interest applies to your situation. questions.question: If the processing of personal data is based on consent, does the consent fulfil the requirements of the GDPR?

choices.selectedText: Certain requirements have to be met for consent to be a valid basis for processing personal data. Among other things, the data subject must be clearly informed of what their consent is being asked for. Data subjects must have the option to refuse their consent, and withdrawing consent must be as easy as giving it. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/consent-of-the-data-subject

questions.question: What do you do if a data subject wants to withdraw their consent for the processing?

choices.option: We have a clear practice for withdrawals of consent
choices.selectedText: If the processing of personal data is based on the data subject's consent, they must also have the option to withdraw their consent. Withdrawing consent must be as easy as giving it. A data subject can withdraw their consent at any time, free of charge. When consent is withdrawn, the company must cease any processing of the data subject's personal data based on consent. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/consent-of-the-data-subject

questions.question: If the processing of personal data is based on the consent of a child younger than 13, was their consent asked from the child's custodian or other holder of parental responsibility?

choices.selectedText: Data protection legislation typically requires a child to obtain the consent of their custodian or other holder of parental responsibility for using information society services, such as social media and various applications. In Finland, the age limit is 13 years. However, children may use counselling and support services and preventive services without their custodian's consent. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/consent-of-the-data-subject
choices.selectedActions: Good. The consent given by a child's custodian does not lapse automatically when the child is old enough to give their own consent to the use of information society services. However, the child may withdraw the consent themselves after passing the age limit specified by law and, as a controller, you are required to inform the child of this option.

choices.selectedActions: Seek to determine the child's age and verify that the child was old enough to give their consent, or that the consent was given by the child's custodian. Assess the verification measures related to consent in relation to the nature and risks of the processing.

questions.question: Does your company process special categories of personal data, such as data on absences due to illness, trade union membership or coronavirus vaccinations?

choices.selectedText: Special categories of personal data consist of racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, health data, sexual orientation or sex life, as well as genetic or biometric data used to identify individuals. The processing of such data is generally prohibited, but can be permitted in certain exceptional cases. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processing-of-special-categories-of-personal-data
choices.selectedActions: If you process such data, make sure that you have a legitimate basis for derogating from the processing prohibition. Also remember to assess the risks related to such processing. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processing-of-special-categories-of-personal-data

The purpose of the report generated by the tool is to give tips and recommendations. You still need to read and understand the General Data Protection Regulation, and compliance with the report's instructions does not guarantee compliance with the GDPR.
